PCI.BIO:
Brian Levey joined the Mendoza faculty in 2007 after a twenty year legal career, most recently focused on building corporate ethics and compliance programs. He currently teaches the introductory undergraduate business law course, as well as several ethics classes in the undergraduate, graduate and executive programs. Levey is a recipient of the Rev. Edmund P. Joyce, C.S.C., Award for Excellence in Undergraduate Teaching, as well as the Master of Science in Accountancy Dincolo Outstanding Professor Award.
Prior to joining the college of business, Levey was Fannie Mae's Vice President for Ethics. Before that, he was the Director of Compliance and Business Ethics with Smiths Group plc, an international engineering company based in the United Kingdom. Previously, Levey was a deputy ethics officer and associate counsel with MCI (formerly WorldCom and now Verizon Business). He has also been in private practice and served as an adjunct professor at George Mason University, George Washington University, and Northern Virginia Community College.

PASTHIST.TITLE: Vice President, Ethics
PASTHIST.DESC: Led the development and implementation of all activities relating to the company’s code of conduct, including related policies, communication and training. Oversaw the “FM Ethics” line, which fields questions regarding the code and company policies, as well as allegations of potential wrongdoing.

PASTHIST.TITLE: Director of Compliance and Business Ethics
PASTHIST.DESC: Worked with senior management to develop and implement a company-wide compliance and business ethics program for this international engineering company based in the United Kingdom, with over 30,000 employees doing business in over forty countries

PASTHIST.TITLE: Deputy Ethics Officer
PASTHIST.DESC: Selected to join two other company attorneys in establishing the Ethics Office for MCI, a global telecommunications company with 55,000 employees doing business in sixty-five countries.

PASTHIST.TITLE: Associate Counsel
PASTHIST.DESC: Managed Law and Public Policy department with responsibility for MCI Government Markets’ sales to the federal government, international organizations, and related commercial entities.

PASTHIST.TITLE: Assistant Professor (Adjunct)
PASTHIST.DESC: Taught Legal Environment of Business to undergraduate students in School of Management.

PASTHIST.TITLE: Assistant Professor (Adjunct)
PASTHIST.DESC: Taught Contract Law to students in Business Technologies Division.

PASTHIST.TITLE: Assitant General Counsel
PASTHIST.DESC: Counseled senior management of PRC, a then $860 million information technology subsidiary of Black & Decker Corporation, regarding a broad variety of issues involving contract, intellectual property, employment, and corporate law.

PASTHIST.TITLE: Professorial Lecturer in Engineering Law (Adjunct)
PASTHIST.DESC: Taught Engineering Law to graduate students in School of Engineering and Applied Science, Department of Engineering Management.

PASTHIST.TITLE: Associate
PASTHIST.DESC: Provided litigation and counseling services to some of the nation's largest government contractors.

PASTHIST.TITLE: Associate
PASTHIST.DESC: Participated in counseling and litigation relating primarily to government contract and employment law.

MEMBER.NAME: Society for Business Ethics
MEMBER.DESC: The Society for Business Ethics is an international organization providing a forum for those interested in research, teaching, or the practical application of ethical principles and concepts to the management of businesses.

MEMBER.NAME: Sports Lawyers Association
MEMBER.DESC: The Sports Lawyers Association (SLA) is a non-profit, international, professional organization whose common goal is the understanding, advancement and ethical practice of sports law. There are over 1,000 current members: practicing lawyers, law educators, law students, and other professionals with an interest in law relating to professional and amateur sports.

MEMBER.NAME: Academy of Legal Studies in Business
MEMBER.DESC: Founded in 1924, the Academy of Legal Studies in Business (International) is an association of teachers and scholars in the fields of business law, legal environment, and law-related courses outside of professional law schools.

MEMBER.NAME: Ethics & Compliance Officer Association
MEMBER.DESC: The Ethics & Compliance Officer Association (ECOA) is a member-driven association for individuals responsible for their organization's ethics, compliance, and business conduct programs. Its members represent the largest group of ethics and compliance practitioners in the world.

MEMBER.NAME: American Accounting Association
MEMBER.DESC: The American Accounting Association is the largest community of accountants in academia. Founded in 1916, it touts a rich and reputable history built on leading-edge research and publications.

INTELLCONT.PUBLISHER: Teaching with Technology Volume 2: The Stories Continue, Learning Technology Consortium
INTELLCONT.TITLE: In-Class Polling: Less Teaching, More Learning?
INTELLCONT.ABSTRACT: Hoping to improve the classroom experience, Professor Levey used an online audience-response system that allows students to answer questions via text message or over the web. He coupled the technology with good questioning techniques and other effective teaching strategies. Both students and professor thought the system helped enhance learning and make class more engaging.

INTELLCONT.TITLE: Tortious Government Conduct and the Government Contract: Tort, Breach of Contract or Both?

INTELLCONT_OTHER.TITLE: Shenandoah Univeristy’s Study-Abroad Program

PRESENT.NAME: 15th Annual Midwest Conference on Scholarship of Teaching & Learning
PRESENT.ORG: Indiana University South Bend
PRESENT.TITLE: Using Film Clips in the Classroom: Something Old, Something New?
PRESENT.ABSTRACT: Ever struggle to engage your students? This presentation will demonstrate how to integrate film clips into the classroom, including: o theme days, where examples from a particular movie, TV show or actor’s tabloid lifestyle are used throughout a class session to explain a particular topic; and o review sessions, during which students apply material to a scene from a movie in preparation for a test.
